AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: Court where trial was held and made oral findings of fact regarding the constitutionality of a stop and search, applying the Brignoni-Ponce standard; exercised discretion in giving the Allen charge; believed Stanley Pruszenski and Alfred Baron's undisputed testimony
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol: law enforcement agency involved in border surveillance, control, and immigration inspections, with agents operating on roving patrol and making stops based on reasonable suspicion; its agents had recently apprehended illegal alien smugglers at or near the location of a specific stop and were entitled to question occupants about their citizenship and immigration status after a stop; observed suspicious behavior such as ducking and scrambling around in a pickup truck camper
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.5th Circuit Court of Appeals: a court that considers the totality of particular circumstances in cases, including stops by roving border patrol agents near the U.S.-Mexican border, and has made rulings on probable cause and upheld the use of the modified Allen charge
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States-Mexican border: geographic location relevant to border surveillance and immigration inspections where highways intersect; a geographical location relevant to the case, referenced in determining reasonable suspicion
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States: country with constitutional protections, differentiating from police states in its prohibition against unreasonable searches
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia: defendant in the case who was stopped on Interstate Highway 35 while driving a pickup truck camper and whose unkempt appearance was alleged to be consistent with that of an illegal alien; claims passengers' actions were attempts to avoid eye contact with flashlight
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Court: the court making decisions on stops by immigration agents
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Interstate Highway 35: highway where Maria De Jesus Garcia was stopped
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Pena-Cantu case: court case referenced for its relevance to the reasonableness of a stop based on suspicious behavior
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Lourdes Rangel-Campos: individual whose appearance, along with that of Maria De Jesus Garcia and others, was considered in determining reasonable suspicion for a stop
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Stanley Pruszenski: agent who made the assessment of the occupants' appearances as dirty or unkempt; testified about passengers' actions when light was shone into pickup truck camper
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Alfred Baron: agent involved in the case; testified about observing passengers ducking and trying to hide when he turned on his flashlight
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.5th Circuit Court of Appeals in this con: court presented with factors for consideration in light of the precedents of this circuit, considering the totality of particular circumstances in cases involving stops by roving border patrol agents near the U.S.-Mexican border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States-Mexican border in this cas: border referenced in determining reasonable suspicion, relevant to the distance from the stop location
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S. Border Patrol: employer of Stanley Pruszenski and Alfred Baron as border patrol agents
